steps.title: Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C).
steps.content: Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C). Make sure one of the racks inside the oven is in the center position before preheating your oven. Don’t cook anything in the oven until it’s completely heated or else your food will not cook evenly. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the skin from one side of the duck legs.
steps.content: Remove the skin from one side of the duck legs. Use a thin chef’s knife to slice into the skin on each duck leg. Slide the knife underneath the skin to separate it from the meat. Only remove the skin from one side so you can enjoy the crispy skin once it’s cooked. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Crisp the skin on the duck legs in a skillet over medium heat for 15 minutes.
steps.content: Crisp the skin on the duck legs in a skillet over medium heat for 15 minutes. Lay the duck legs so the skin side is down. Leave the legs in the pan until the skin gets brown and crispy, which should take around 15 minutes at medium heat. [4] X Research source You don’t need to add any additional cooking oils since the legs will cook in the duck fat. Use a large skillet that can hold all of the ingredients and is safe to use in the oven.

steps.title: Peel and dice the onion, carrots, and celery while the duck legs cook.
steps.content: Peel and dice the onion, carrots, and celery while the duck legs cook. Remove the outer skin from the onion with your hands and use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin from your carrots. Use a chef’s knife and a cutting board to dice the veggies so they are 1 ⁄ 2 by 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 by 1.3 cm) cubes. This ensures that they cook evenly. [5] X Research source Use any root vegetables you want, such as parsnips or scallions, for different flavors.

steps.title: Sear the skinless side of the duck leg for 2 minutes and move them to a plate.
steps.content: Sear the skinless side of the duck leg for 2 minutes and move them to a plate. Flip the duck legs using a spatula and let the exposed meat sear. This will help further lock the juices in the meat. After they’re finished, transfer them to plate skin-side up and let them rest. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Brown the vegetables in the duck fat for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.content: Brown the vegetables in the duck fat for 10 to 15 minutes. Place all of the vegetables into the skillet along with the duck fat. Stir them occasionally with a wooden spoon so all of the veggies cook through and soften evenly. [7] X Research source You can drain up to two-thirds of the duck fat if you want, but it’s not necessary.

steps.title: Put the duck back in the pan and add the chicken stock.
steps.content: Put the duck back in the pan and add the chicken stock. Set the duck on top of the vegetables so the crispy skin is facing up. Pour in 2 cups (470 ml) of chicken stock into the skillet so half of the duck is submerged. Don’t get the skin wet or else it will turn soggy and rubbery. [8] X Research source You can purchase chicken stock at your grocery store or make your own!

steps.title: Bring the skillet to a boil over high heat.
steps.content: Bring the skillet to a boil over high heat. Turn up the heat and let the stock boil for 1 minute. Once it’s been boiling, turn your stove off completely. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Place the skillet in the oven for 30 minutes.
steps.content: Place the skillet in the oven for 30 minutes. Use an oven mitt to hold the skillet handle and set the skillet on the center rack of the oven. Set a timer for 30 minutes and avoid opening the door so heat doesn’t escape. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Reduce the heat to 350 °F (177 °C) and cook for another 30 minutes.
steps.content: Reduce the heat to 350 °F (177 °C) and cook for another 30 minutes. Once your timer goes off, lower the heat and set another 30-minute timer. When the duck is finished, it should easily be pierced with a knife. Serve the duck legs and vegetables while they’re still hot. [11] X Research source The duck will stay warm in the oven for 1 hour after it’s finished cooking. Use a meat thermometer to make sure the duck is 165 °F (74 °C) in the thickest part of the leg.

steps.title: Refrigerate the duck for 3-4 days.
steps.content: Refrigerate the duck for 3-4 days. Place the duck in an airtight container or a resealable plastic bag. Make sure to put the leftovers in the fridge within 2 hours after cooking it. Otherwise, harmful bacteria could form on the meat. [12] X Research source Duck can be kept in the freezer for up to 3 months.

steps.title: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.content: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C). Set one of the racks to the center position in your oven before you turn it on. Make sure the oven is fully heated before cooking in it. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Poke holes in the duck legs with a wooden skewer.
steps.content: Poke holes in the duck legs with a wooden skewer. Stab into the skin side of the meat with a skewer, making sure you don’t go all the way through it. Aim to have 15-20 holes on the duck leg. The holes allow for the duck fat to release while it is cooking. [14] X Research source Use a fork to poke multiple holes at the same time.

steps.title: Brush the legs with olive oil and season it with salt and pepper.
steps.content: Brush the legs with olive oil and season it with salt and pepper. Spread 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of olive oil across the entire surface of the meat with a kitchen brush. Sprinkle on salt and pepper until you have the level of seasoning you desire, but be careful of over salting the meat. [15] X Research source Use other spices like thyme or red pepper flake to add more aromatic flavors to your duck.

steps.title: Place the duck legs on a baking sheet with a wire rack.
steps.content: Place the duck legs on a baking sheet with a wire rack. Spray the cooking sheet and wire rack with cooking oil so your duck doesn’t stick. Put the baking tray with the duck legs on the center rack of the oven. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Cook the legs for 90 minutes.
steps.content: Cook the legs for 90 minutes. Keep the door closed while the duck is cooking so you don’t let any of the heat out. After 75 minutes, check the internal temperature of the duck legs with a meat thermometer. If it isn’t at 165 °F (74 °C), let it cook for the last 15 minutes. [17] X Research source Sanitize your meat thermometer with dish soap before using it again if the duck wasn’t cooked to temperature.

steps.title: Cover the duck with foil and allow it to rest for 10 minutes after cooking.
steps.content: Cover the duck with foil and allow it to rest for 10 minutes after cooking. Remove the duck legs from the oven and immediately wrap the tray in aluminum foil to keep the duck warm. Let the legs rest for 10 minutes before serving them. [18] X Research source Roast duck pairs well with wild rice.

steps.title: Store the duck in the fridge for up to 4 days.
steps.content: Store the duck in the fridge for up to 4 days. Keep the duck legs in an airtight plastic container or a plastic storage bag. Put your leftovers in the fridge within 2 hours so harmful bacteria doesn’t form. [19] X Research source Keep duck in the freezer for up to 3 months.
